now WE CAN TURN OUR ATTENTION TO THE 4TH Amendment. Which is where this conversation should have started.

I' just going to leave a slight margin of doubt, but I think Joe Manchin at least is going to reconsider his vote in the next 48 hours. One thing will lead to another. Even without proof by the FBI, the media will create the kind of pressure that perhaps even more people, even Republicans will change their vote. Because even a hint of doubt about Kavanaugh will make his position untenable.
and Chrisp is right - a motion to reconsider but the question will have been answered.

It has been confirmed by multiple sources that Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh has a sufficient amount of votes to be elected to the Supreme Court because Senator Susan Collins, Jeff Flake, and Joe Manchin. Currently, it is highly probable that Brett Kavanaugh will be confirmed 51-49. (https://www.cnn.com/2018/10/05/politics/kavanaugh-nomination-vote-friday/index.html) Thus, "swing vote" senators would need to change their vote from supporting Kavanaugh to opposing him to prevent him from being confirmed, as a 50-50 tie would result in Vice President Pence being the tie-breaking vote.
A look from a libertarian publication at Avenatti's involvement:
Collins has announced to vote yes. Chance of surprises at least 3%
Updating on Collins’ announced yes vote.

The Hill reports that Collins says she'll vote "Yes".
Confirmation isn't a lock, but it's sure looking likely.

Flake has announced he'll be a "Yes"
Donnelly had previously said he'd be a "No"
US Senate approves sending Kavanaugh nomination to final vote
with only 1 defecting GOP senator it will pass. But they have the benefit of a scab Dem senator. https://thehill.com/homenews/senate/410074-manchin-murkowski-break-ranks-on-key-kavanaugh-vote
The successful cloture vote raises the likelihood that the Republicans have the votes to confirm Kavanaugh.
Collins, Murkowski, have made positive comments about the FBI report.  I think the election is in the bag.

Republicans aim to confirm Kavanaugh this weekend; protesters arrested
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-court-kavanaugh/fully-confident-white-house-receives-fbi-report-on-kavanaugh-idUSKCN1ME0Z1
It seems that there's fairly wide agreement that there's 5 swing votes:  2 Democrats (Manchin & Donnelly) and 3 Republicans (Flake, Collins & Murkowski).
With R senators leaning toward yes reportedly it seems like that's all she wrote.

CNN reports swing GOP senators leaning yes. https://www.cnn.com/2018/10/04/politics/kavanaugh-vote-murkowski-collins-flake-trump/index.html
Predictit is at 85% and rising. I tend to think Predictit has a Dem bias, so call that 87%.

Moving back to 95%. Collins & Flake appears to be moving towards yes. If so, Murkowski not needed. Pence is tie breaker. If Manchin votes against, he becomes seriously endangered despite his edge in likability. Can’t see how McConnell would have announced a vote this week if he didn’t already know the outcome.

+32. Heitkamp has come out against. Four are left. Manchin, Flake, Murkowski, and Collins. The three Republicans are saying it was a thorough investigation. To my mind, this makes confirmation much more likely despite the probable negative backlash to Murkowski and Collins in either event.

Soon-to-be-former Senator Heitkamp says she'll vote "No" on Kavanaugh. But every Democrat and one Republican (i.e. Flake) can vote against confirmation and Kavanaugh still gets on the Supreme Court. Two Republicans defect, and Kavanaugh doesn't make it. But that seems unlikely.
Key senators reacting positively to the FBI report as mentioned by @Prognosticating-Beek here https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/778238

increased odds from the comments of the only senators that matter:
https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/senate-judiciary-receives-fbi-report-kavanaugh-allegations/story?id=58277222

The lead withholding GOP senator, flake, gave words today that indicated he liked the FBI report. This is a large signal he will vote yes. Also Collins said it was "thorough"   That pushes my estimate that either will vote yes to 80%. As they are dependent, the math is simple= .8x.8=.64  Factor in Murks vote at .3 which will raise the chances, plus a scab Dem who might vote and I arrive at 75%

+4% due to deepened partisan divide. Red state waverers such as Manchin will have a hard time voting no. https://www.politico.com/story/2018/10/01/poll-kavanaugh-ford-opinion-854860 and https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/politics-podcast-what-the-new-polling-on-kavanaugh-means/

Increasing 6%. The FBI report has been submitted. 9 people were interviewed and the broader question around drinking (where Kavanaugh may have dissembled and potentially perjured himself) was not explored. This suggests that not only is it unlikely for the FBI to corroborate Dr. Blasey’s allegation but the report may also leave Kavanaugh’s credibility largely intact, giving hesitant Republicans plenty of cover.

Today, the National Council of Churches, representing 100,000 congregations and 45 million churchgoers across an array of Christian denominations in the U.S. has called for the nomination of Brett Kavanaugh to be withdrawn.   Their statement said, “Judge Kavanaugh exhibited extreme partisan bias and disrespect towards certain members of the committee and thereby demonstrated that he possesses neither the temperament nor the character essential for a member of the highest court in our nation.” The statement also alleged misstatements and “outright falsehoods” in his testimony.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  I'm asking myself what might motivate one of the swing votes to vote yes or no:  Public opinion?  Would this action by the National Council of Churches, and recent withdrawal of an endorsement of Kavanaugh by the Catholic Jesuits and the American Bar Association?  Or would those bodies influence the voting public which would then bring pressure to bear on their senators?
Vote has been scheduled for Saturday. Results of additional background check would have to contain new substantive findings.

+10% FBI was hamstrung to do any real investigation and was not permitted to talk w/ Dr Ford or delve into drinking issues of Kav. Unlikely to reveal anything and should be considered a political sham investigation. Interestingly, both political parties are incensed by the hearing, and the GOP will unlikely have many defectors aside from Flake and the other 2.  I give Collin and Murk each a 30% to vote for Kav.

Adding 6 with the FBI rumored to be wrapping up sooner than I expected. It seems quite plausible that the bureau's report will contain enough ambiguity for each side to be able to cherry pick its own conclusions.

We'll know this week. The problem for the Kavanaugh nomination is that even if red state Democrats vote to confirm him, they will probably lose anyway. However, if they vote him down, they will definitely lose, and have effectively given up their seats. I still think Kavanugh will be confirmed, but by now, red state Democrats have little reason to vote Kavanaugh on to the Supreme Court. We may wind up with a Pence tie-breaker.

The investigating will not stop even when the FBI stops.  He just partied and drank too much to not have screwed up on these and/or other occasions.   Once a few Senators see this, they may choose to not back him.
3) and even if he's defeated there will be another appointed in his place.

2) Even if 1 or 2 Republicans don't support him, 1 or 2 Democrats running for re-election in red states will vote for him.

I'm lowering conservatively for now. I think the FBI investigation will clarify a great deal.  I suspect that it won't be as hard as Kavanaugh expects to find evidence of his drinking days, and I think that even is some of his friends, acquaintances, or enemies from high school and college remember damaging or suggestive stuff and can give more detail than has been given, it will be bad for him.  He may have come very close to perjuring himself on the stand in that hearing Thursday, and I think the discussion may very easily turn from an alleged attempted rape of Blasey Ford, which is hard to prove, to a drinking issue and how severe and frequent it really was, which is perhaps much easier to come by.  And if the stories come out in the same way over a week (or more), it may be much harder to say that what happened in high school or college stays in high school or college.
With Sen. Dan Sullivan's emergency surgery, flake has pulled a Fiat Accompli. It'll take a lame duck session to confirm him now.

Without search warrants or subpoenas, the FBI may fail to discover corroborating evidence. One of my main hypotheses is that within the short frame and limitations of the investigation the FBI will turn up some evidence that boosts Blasey’s credibility (eg marching details) but nothing directly confirming. https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/28/us/politics/kavanauagh-fbi-background-check.html

The hurry-up FBI "investigation" will provide just enough ambiguity to give cover to just enough Rs and red-state Ds to make this very close indeed.   I'm inclined to think Kavanaugh dies on the floor unless The Leader Of The Free World uses his tiny little fingers to pull the plug on him first.  I am probably wrong.

-15% Week delay will let the Senators get feedback of angry constituents(-6%), allow the FBI to bring forward something corroborating Dr Ford (-5%) or something entirely new (-1%).  Then the chance for buyers remorse to kick in (-3%) as wives and daughters of Senators exert home diplomacy.

Dropping 92% -->82% based on the 1 week delay. This provides political cover for the votes on the fence and also allows them to get better data on how the hearings change the political calculus of the votes.

Now the question is about what kind of evidence the FBI may turn up. Given that there are consistencies between Dr. Blasey’s testimony, Kavanaughs calendar and Judge’s book, it’s plausible that something incriminating will be found. There are also the people who in interviews confirmed behavior patterns consistent with the allegation.

Maybe I spoke too soon; looks like a week's delay for an FBI investigation. But I'm staying at 100%, because I consider it more likely that an FBI investigation will provide cover for pro-Kavanaugh votes than sink his nomination.
-13% Delay request though with Manchin they can push it through.
-2% for Flake and Murkowski wanting delay.

Clearly, McConnell does not currently have the votes. 
Flake wants a week delay for an FBI investigation to proceed. Murkowski supports Flake on this.

-5% as Collins(D) is now taking meetings with assault survivors indicating she'll be voting NO. Donnaly(D) is a NO officially.  That is 2 of 3 swing D senators who voted with GOP last confirmation.  Flake(R) is a yes for bring Kav to a vote.

I think it’s likely, therefore, that Corker is also a yes. That leaves Murkowski and Collins as the key holdouts. Both have to be “no” votes to sink the nomination. Possible, but I now think Kavanaugh has slightly better than even odds to make it through.

Back up. For senators who were on the fence, I think there will be a greater potential cost for voting against Kavanaugh, so I consider it likely that he'll be confirmed.

+5% Republicans on the Judiciary Committee (with the help of Kavanaugh ‘s caustic testimony) have managed to make the Kavanaugh vote less about Dr. Blasey’s allegation and more about whether to let Democrats sabotage a confirmation by deploying uncorrovorated allegations. This partisan narrative may be enough to protect vulnerable Republicans in the midterms from the metoo movement. As a note to self, partisanship is a potent force that I have underestimated before. Moreover, there is no rule or norm that says that the committee has to bring in Judge to testify (though many believe that would be the right thing to do if you are after the truth), so I don’t see much standing in the way other than two or three hesitant Republicans that can be brought in line as the R party has done before.

Hers are the most damning allegations if proven, but also the easiest to shoot down if no one else comes forward to corroborate them. Kind of doubting that there will be a hearing tomorrow as there is a 4th and perhaps 5th accusation at this point. Trump may dump K because he doesn't want to lose the vote. Can a new nominee get in before the mid-terms with 41 days left or do they need a little distance from this one first?
I think Kavanaughs chances have vastly diminished in the last few days. Too many allegations, too little time.

I may watch some or all of the testimony at the hearing tomorrow. But for purposes of forecasting, the post-mortem in the press will be much more important. If there is no testimony from the accusers - as it is rumored will be the case, Kavanaugh will almost certainly be confirmed.

Even more likely that Ford wont show.... 
Intentionally unrealistic demands.
She wont risk perjury.

Adjusting forecast. With the vote on Friday and a polarized senate Kavanaugh may still be confirmed because the GOP feels it has the votes. However:
1. No one this unpopular has ever been confirmed to the Supreme Court; the only previous nominees who polled as poorly as Kavanaugh either had their names withdrawn (Harriet Miers) or lost their confirmation vote (Robert Bork). This was using polling from before more accusers stepped forward.
2. If Kavanaugh withdraws, there is insufficient time to confirm another justice based on historical trends.
-5% on rumors more accusers are coming out.

McConnell thinks he has the votes and they appear to be voting a day after Ford testifies. I'm not thrilled about reversing myself again, but it appears that the additional accusations have only hardened positions. Also, polling analysis on 538 seem to indicate that this story is seen primarily through the lens of partisanship, like most other issues of the day. It would appear that Republicans are facing consequences for voting him down rather than supporting him at this point.

If this it true.... this guy is God Level Troll.....lol those /pol/ trolls! So organized! Lol
https://twitter.com/JayTrollsteinII/status/1044611670612594688

I think for purposes of forecasting this question, the number of accusers is far less important than how convincing they are when they testify. And so far neither Ford nor Ramirez has been able to produce a corroborating witness. That doesn't mean they won't - I don't know, and neither does anybody else on GJO, the protestations of certainty on both sides notwithstanding.

---correcting math edit ----
I'm getting really torn on this update. On one hand, there is fading support for Kav from the GOP side. Fading meaning there are 3 senators likely to vote no and an unknown quantity who may vote no. The Dems will likely lock ranks and vote no, with a remote possibility of 1 or 2 defectors. I'd give the vote a 60% chance to fail. On the other hand, the GOP may be desperate enough to ram thru a vote and the GOP senators are so desperate, that even if they think Kav is guilty they want to get Kav on the bench to overturn Roe v Wade as they find abortion the greater evil. This option is less likely.
Then bear in mind that a GOP senate and a GOP WH can run a nominee thru fast according to history https://www.nbcnews.com/card/how-long-does-it-take-confirm-supreme-court-judge-n735771 The only question is if the past senates where this occured were treated well by the WH and due to that lubricity there was bipartisan support. If that were the case, it would not apply to this Senate which is highly partisan and combative. So I do not have faith in a short nominee confirmation cycle. Further, October will have most the House out and some of the Senate out to campaign. So I think Kav's confirmation hearing is it. Maybe 5% chance to cycle in another nominee and confirm?
In the end, perhaps the chance of a vote passing is 50% and not 40%, and the chance of a 2nd is 8% not 5%. So 58?

I think there's more to come.   I still think Mark Judge is a bit of a weak link, too.  I think this week will continue to be a crazy ride, but I think by early next week Republicans will try to pull it all back together for a final vote.  They don't want to backtrack and have every motivational reason for digging in their heels.  And the longer this rolls out, the worse the public political backlash will be (for both sides) as it makes both sides look bad and increases the likelihood of every angry person going to the polls in the midterms, which usually doesn't work out so well for incumbents.  Also, they need another judge on the bench now for the Oct session of SCOTUS and they need it before the midterms, which are too close to gamble with.  So Republicans have a lot to lose but most to lose from any further delay, and submitting a new name almost certainly means a delay beyond the timeline of the question.

      Then bear in mind that a GOP senate and a GOP WH can run a nominee thru fast according to history https://www.nbcnews.com/card/how-long-does-it-take-confirm-supreme-court-judge-n735771   The only question is if the past senates where this occured were treated well by the WH and due to that lubricity there was bipartisan support. The Psychology of the Unthinkable: Taboo Trade-Offs, Forbidden Base Rates, and Heretical Counterfactuals
Philip E. Tetlock, Orie V. Kristel, S. Beth Elson, and Melanie C. Green Ohio Stale University
Jennifer S. Lerner Carnegie Mellon University
Five studies explored cognitive, affective, and behavioral responses to proscribed forms of social cognition. Experiments 1 and 2 revealed that people responded to taboo trade-offs that monetized sacred values with moral outrage and cleansing. Experiments 3 and 4 revealed that racial egalitarians were least likely to use, and angriest at those who did use, race-tainted base rates and that egalitarians who inadvertently used such base rates tried to reaffirm their fair-mindedness. Experiment 5 revealed that Christian fundamentalists were most likely to reject heretical counterfactuals that applied everyday causal schemata to Biblical narratives and to engage in moral cleansing after merely contemplating such possibilities. Although the results fit the sacred-value-protection model (SVPM) better than rival formulations, the SVPM must draw on cross-cultural taxonomies of relational schemata to specify normative boundaries on thought.

On the special counsel, presidential pardons, and impeachment, the most important decisions will be rendered not by judges or senators but by the American people
We are having a “constitutional moment,” so to speak, in two parts. The first is obvious and momentous; the second is less obvious, but perhaps even more significant. The first is Justice Anthony Kennedy’s retirement and the fight to confirm his successor; the second is a slow-motion collision of profound constitutional powers: those of prosecution, pardon, and impeachment. For the first, we are mainly spectators; the second will call ultimately for our own deliberation and decision.

The U.S. Senate confirmed seven nominees to federal district courts on Tuesday, where they will serve lifetime terms. With the seven confirmations, the U.S. Senate has now confirmed 60 federal judges--33 district court judges, 26 appeals court judges, and one Supreme Court justice (Neil Gorsuch)--nominated by President Donald Trump (R).

President Donald Trump's nominee to be the next Supreme Court justice -- Judge Brett Kavanaugh -- will start his Senate confirmation hearings on September 4, the Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley announced Friday.
"He's met with dozens of senators who have nothing but positive things to say," Grassley, an Iowa Republican, said in a statement. "At this current pace, we have plenty of time to review the rest of emails and other records that we will receive from President Bush and the National Archives. It's time for the American people to hear directly from Judge Kavanaugh at his public hearing."
Grassley said he expects the hearing to last three or four days.

The New Civil Liberties Alliance (NCLA), a public interest law firm with a focus on the administrative state, published an assessment of Kavanaugh’s approach to legal issues involving the administrative state. Here are takeaways:
Kavanaugh would oppose attempts by agencies to exercise legislative, executive and judicial functions.
Kavanaugh has raised concerns in judicial opinions about ongoing violations of the U.S. Constitution’s separation of powers.
He contends that the judicial branch has enabled, rather than checked, Congressional delegations of authority to the executive branch.
Kavanaugh has a critical record of Chevron deference—the practice of federal courts deferring to a agency interpretations of ambiguous statutory language.
He has described the principle as “an a textual invention by the courts” that shifts power from Congress to the executive branch. He has described independent agencies as the “headless fourth branch of the U.S. Government,” and warned that they threaten individual liberties and the system of checks and balances.

On July 9, President Donald Trump nominated Brett Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court. Kavanaugh is a federal judge on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit. He was appointed by former President George W. Bush on February 25, 2006.

Sen. Chuck Grassley (R), chair of the Senate Judiciary Committee, stated earlier this week that the confirmation hearings for Brett Kavanaugh will likely be held in early September. Let’s catch up on recent events.  The Judicial Crisis Network began a new round of ads this week targeting U.S. Senate Democrats in West Virginia, North Dakota, Indiana, and Alabama. This ad buy brought the network's total spending in support of Kavanaugh's confirmation to $5.3 million. In West Virginia (Joe Manchin), North Dakota (Heidi Heitkamp), and Indiana (Joe Donnelly), Democratic incumbents are involved in battleground midterm re-election campaigns. Both the Judicial Crisis Network (pro-Kavanaugh confirmation) and Demand Justice (opposed to Kavanaugh confirmation) have been spending money since the nomination announcement. Demand Justice plans to spend $5 million throughout the confirmation process. A Quinnipiac University poll found that 41 percent of voters thought the Senate should not confirm Kavanaugh, while 40 percent thought it should. The one-point difference was within the poll’s +/- 3.4 percent margin of error. Kavanaugh met with Sen. Rand Paul (R) on Tuesday. Sen. Joe Manchin (D) said he will meet with Kavanaugh on July 30, becoming the first Democratic senator to schedule a meeting with the judge. Sen. Chuck Schumer (D) said he would not meet with Kavanaugh until the Republican and Democratic leaders of the Senate Judiciary Committee agreed on which documents about Kavanaugh's history should be released.
